name: Greek BA
overview: The Greek major is a designated capstone major. Undergraduate students take a capstone seminar in which they use the skills and expertise acquired in earlier coursework to research, analyze, and complete a written paper or project. They identify and analyze ancient classical documents, material evidence, or other forms of primary sources and demonstrate their critical skills by engaging in presentations and weekly discourse with their peers.

sections.title: The Major
sections.description: Complete 11 courses as follows: seven upper-division Greek courses, including course 110; three upper-division courses in classical civilization and/or ancient history; and one capstone seminar.

requirements.title: Upper-Division Greek Courses
requirements.description: Complete seven upper-division Greek courses, including GREEK 110. The remaining six courses are chosen from other upper-division Greek offerings. GREEK 197 and GREEK 199 may be applied by petition.

sections.title: Honors Program
sections.description: Admission: The honors program is open to Greek majors with a cumulative grade-point average (GPA) of 3.5 or better in departmental courses and an overall GPA of 3.25 or better. Students with lower GPAs may petition for admission. All honors students are required to take Classics 191 (or an equivalent undergraduate seminar) in their junior year before beginning work on the honors thesis. Graduation requirements: To graduate with departmental honors, students must have a cumulative GPA of 3.5 or better in departmental courses, an overall GPA of 3.25 or better, and complete Classics 198A and 198B with grades of Aâ€“ or better. To graduate with departmental highest honors, students must have a cumulative GPA of 3.85 or better in departmental courses, an overall GPA of 3.65 or better, and complete Classics 198A and 198B with grades of A.

requirements.title: Honors Thesis
requirements.description: Students write the thesis under the direct supervision of a faculty member over two consecutive terms, Classics 198A and 198B. In course 198A, students submit an annotated bibliography and preliminary outline of their thesis. In course 198B, they submit at least one initial draft and the final revised version of the thesis. Only course 198B may be applied toward the upper-division classical civilization requirement for departmental majors.
